etymology_text: From Proto-Italic *fāmā, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰéh₂meh₂, from *bʰeh₂- (“to speak”). Cognate to Ancient Greek φήμη (phḗmē, “talk”).

examples.text: hascine propter rēs maledicās fāmās ferunt.
examples.english: Is it on account of these things that they spread slanderous reports?

examples.text: “Oenōtrī coluēre virī; nunc fāma minōrēs
examples.english: “Oenotrian men tilled [the land]; now rumor [has it that their] descendants call the nation ‘Italy’ after the name of its leader, [Italus].”
examples.roman: Ītaliam dīxisse ducīs dē nōmine gentem.”

examples.text: Dīmīcantī dē fāmā dēesse.
examples.english: To abandon one whose reputation is attacked.

examples.text: Fāma tamen clāra est; et adhūc sine crīmine vīxī.
examples.ref: 43 BCE – c. 17 CE, Ovid, Heroides 17.17, (translation Benham's Book of Quotations 1948)
examples.english: My good name is nevertheless unstained; and so far I have lived without blame.

examples.text: Multī fāmam, conscientiam paucī verentur.
examples.ref: 61 CE – c. 112 CE, Pliny the Younger, Epistulae 3.20.9
examples.english: Many fear their reputation, few their conscience.

examples.text:
Extemplō Libyae magnās it Fāma per urbēs —
Fāma, malum quā nōn aliud vēlōcius ūllum.
Straightaway Rumor runs through the great cities of Libya – Rumor, than whom [there is] not any other evil more swift.

glosses: Fama, personified as a fast-moving, malicious goddess, the daughter of Terra. From the Greek φήμη, Pheme. Typically translated from the Latin as “Rumor.”

etymology_text: From Proto-Italic *legō, from Proto-Indo-European *leǵ-. Cognates include Ancient Greek λέγω (légō, “I speak, I choose, I mean”) and Albanian mbledh. May be related to lēx.

etymology_templates.name: cog

args.t: I speak, I choose, I mean

etymology_templates.expansion: Ancient Greek λέγω (légō, “I speak, I choose, I mean”)

examples.text: […] dum ne quem militem legeret ex eo numero quibus senatus missionem reditumque in patriam negasset ante belli finem.
examples.ref: 27 BCE – 25 BCE, Titus Livius, Ab Urbe Condita 26.1
examples.english: […] provided he did not choose any soldier from those to whom the Senate had refused discharge and a return home before the end of the war

glosses: to take out, pick out, extract, remove

categories.name: Latin heteronyms

glosses: to take to one's self unjustly, carry off, steal, purloin, plunder, abstract

examples.text: Librōs lege.
examples.english: Read books.

examples.text: Lēgistīne hunc librum?
examples.english: Have you read this book?

examples.text: Lingua Graeca est; nōn potest legī.
examples.english: It's Greek; it cannot be read.

examples.text:
Exigis, ut nostrōs dōnem tibi, Tucca, libellōs.
Nōn faciam: nam vīs vēndere, nōn legere.
You demand that I give our [⇒ my] little books to you, Tucca.
examples.english: I will not do [it]: for you want to sell [them], not to read [them].

etymology_text:
From Ancient Greek λείριον (leírion), from Fayyumic Coptic ϩⲗⲏⲣⲓ (hlēri), from Demotic (ḥrry), from Egyptian D2:D21-D21:X1-M2 (ḥrrt, “flower”).
Perhaps also the root of Sanskrit हली (halī), हलिनी (halinī, “lily”).

categories.name: Latin neuter nouns in the second declension

etymology_text: From Proto-Italic *ū̆skʷe, from Proto-Indo-European *úds-kʷe, from *úd-s (“out, outward”, genitive) + *-kʷe (“and”). Cognate with Sanskrit उच्चा (uccā́), Younger Avestan 𐬎𐬯𐬗𐬀 (usca, “up, out”), Russian вы- (vy-, “out from”), Proto-Germanic *ūt, English out.

examples.text:
, Latin Vulgate translation of Psalm 71:8;Canadian national motto
Ā marī ū̆sque ad mare.
examples.english: From sea unto sea.

examples.text: ab ōvō ū̆sque ad māla
examples.english:
from the beginning to the end
(literally, “from the egg to the apples”)

etymology_text: Perfect passive participle of regō (“to keep or lead straight, to guide”). Corresponds to Proto-Indo-European *h₃reǵtós (“having moved in a straight line”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃reǵ- (“to straighten, direct”).

examples.english: Which preserve their order in straight lines

examples.text: Via stultī rēcta in oculīs eius; quī autem sapiēns est audit cōnsilia.
examples.english: The way of a fool is right in his own eyes: but he that is wise hearkeneth unto counsels. (Douay-Rheims trans., Challoner rev.: 1752 CE)

raw_glosses: (in particular) morally right, correct, lawful, just, virtuous, noble, good, proper, honest.

args.1: see there for further descendants; some were later influenced by French

templates.expansion: (see there for further descendants; some were later influenced by French)

descendants.text: → Proto-West Germanic: *dōm (see there for further descendants; some were later influenced by French)

etymology_text:
For Proto-Italic *domos, from Proto-Indo-European *dṓm (“house, home”), from root *dem- (“to build”). Cognates include Ancient Greek δόμος (dómos), Albanian dhomë (“a chamber, a room”), Avestan 𐬛𐬀𐬨- (dam-) Sanskrit दम (dáma), Proto-Slavic *domъ and further to English timber. At least indirectly cognate to Latin dominus.
The feminine gender is probably due to the original root noun; attempts to transfer it to the 4th declension are due to 2nd declension feminines being unusual outside of tree names. Some manuscripts of Plautus show forms in dem-; De Vaan (2008) doubts their authenticity.

derived.english: at home, in the house; adverbial form
I have at home, I have in abundance, I am provided with
home, homewards, to the house; adverbial form
from home, out of the house; at home, in the house; adverbial form
placed outside of the house; refers to a possible result of Catholic ecclesiastical legal proceedings when the culprit is removed from being part of a group like a monastery
for one’s own home or house; serving the interests of a given perspective or for the benefit of a given group

examples.text: Deō domuīque
examples.english: For God and for home (motto of Methodist Ladies' College, Melbourne)

examples.text: Stet fortūna domūs
examples.english: Let the good fortune of the house stand (motto of Harrow School, England)

examples.text: nox erat et tōta lūmina nūlla domō
examples.english: It was night, and [there were] no lights in the whole house.

glosses: house, home (the building where a person lives)
